questions.text: Which of the following is / are management options for Shield ulcer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Shield ulcers are classically seen in Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).
  • They result from mechanical trauma by giant papillae and inflammatory mediators damaging the corneal epithelium.
  • Management options include:
    • Surface Debridement (Option A): Removal of necrotic epithelium helps in faster healing and prevents further stromal involvement.
    • Amniotic Membrane Graft (Option B): Provides a biological bandage, anti-inflammatory effect, and promotes epithelial healing.
    • Bandage Contact Lens (Option C): Protects the corneal surface from trauma by eyelid movements and reduces pain.

choices.text: All are variants of allergic conjunctivitis.
Ropy discharge and itching is characteristic

questions.text: What is common to Hay fever conjunctivitis, Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis and Giant Papillary conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All are variants of allergic conjunctivitis (Option A):

Variants of Allergic conjunctivitis:

  • Seasonal allergic or 'hay fever' conjunctivitis.
  • Perennial allergic conjunctivitis.
  • Vernal conjunctivitis or keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).
  • Atopic keratoconjunctivitis (AKC).
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC).
  • Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis.
  • Contact dermatokeratoconjunctivitis.

Mediated by IgE (Option B):

  • Type I hypersensitivity reactions to pollen and other atmospheric exogenous allergens mediated by IgE play an important role. This indicates that IgE mediation is a common factor in these types of conjunctivitis.

Ropy discharge and itching are characteristic (Option C):

  • Itching is a prominent symptom, along with redness and watery secretion, which is not purulent, and a whitish, ropy discharge is characteristic. This confirms that ropy discharge and itching are common characteristics of these types of conjunctivitis.

choices.text: Anti-biotics are required in cases with corneal implication
Cycloplegic is added in cases with corneal involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regards to management of phlyctenular conjunctivitis is/ are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Option A: Response to steroids is good.

This statement is correct. Topical steroids are the first-line treatment for phlyctenular conjunctivitis. They are very effective in reducing inflammation and relieving symptoms.

Option B: Anti-biotics are required in cases with corneal implication.

This statement is also correct. If the cornea is involved in phlyctenular conjunctivitis, antibiotics are necessary to prevent infection.

Option C: Cycloplegic is added in cases with corneal involvement.

This statement is correct. A cycloplegic is a type of eye drop that paralyzes the muscles that control the pupil. It is used in cases of corneal involvement to reduce pain and spasm.

Option D: Dark glasses help with photophobia.

This statement is incorrect. Photophobia is a sensitivity to light. Dark glasses may help with photophobia in other conditions, such as dry eye or uveitis, but they are not helpful in phlyctenular conjunctivitis. In fact, dark glasses may actually delay the resolution of the inflammation in phlyctenular conjunctivitis.

Now, lets know better about Phlyctenular conjuctivitis.

Definition:

Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type of inflammation of the conjunctiva (the clear tissue that covers the white part of the eye). It is characterized by the formation of small, round, grey or yellow nodules on the conjunctiva.

Causes:

Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is thought to be caused by an allergic reaction to bacterial proteins, most commonly from tuberculosis or other mild, long-standing infections such as those of the tonsils or adenoids.

Symptoms:

The symptoms of phlyctenular conjunctivitis include:

  • Discomfort
  • Irritation
  • Reflex lacrimation (excessive tearing)

If the cornea is involved, there may also be:

  • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
  • Pain
  • Blurred vision

Diagnosis:

The diagnosis of phlyctenular conjunctivitis is based on the patient's medical history and physical examination. The doctor will look for the presence of phlyctenules on the conjunctiva.

Treatment:

Treatment for phlyctenular conjunctivitis typically includes:

  • Topical steroids to reduce inflammation
  • Antibiotics to prevent infection if the cornea is involved

In some cases, other treatments such as cycloplegics (eye drops that paralyze the muscles that control the pupil) or bandage contact lenses may be necessary.

Prognosis:

Most people with phlyctenular conjunctivitis make a full recovery. However, some people may have recurrent episodes of the condition.

Reference: Parson’s Diseases of the Eye-Edition 23-Chap 11-Diseases of the Conjunctiva

choices.text: Associated history of Asthma/ allergic rhinitis frequently noted

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Atopic kerato-conjunctivitis are true except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atopic keratoconjunctivitis manifests in early adulthood and extends into adulthood, and is not seen in children.

Atopic Keratoconjunctivitis:

Associated Atopic Diseases(Option B):

  • Asthma
  • Allergic rhinitis
  • Atopic eczematoid dermatitis in the patient or their family.

Disease Characteristics:

  • Responsible for an extremely severe and chronic form of ocular surface disorder.
  • The disease spectrum varies in range of severity, ranging from mild cases to chronic and persistent inflammation.

Comparison to VKC (Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis): Similar to VKC but tends to be more:

  • Severe(Option C)
  • Chronic
  • Extends into adulthood.

choices.text: Pathology is loss of hemidesmosomal attachment of epithelium to basement membrane
Multiple remissions and exacerbations are common

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Ocular Pemphigoid are true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ocular Cicatricial Pemphigoid (OCP):

  • Mucous membrane pemphigoid (MMP), also known as ocular cicatricial pemphigoid (OCP), comprises a group of chronic autoimmune mucocutaneous blistering diseases.
  • An unknown trigger leads to a Type II (cytotoxic) hypersensitivity response, resulting in antibodies binding at the basement membrane zone (BMZ), the activation of complement and the recruitment of inflammatory cells, with localised separation of the epidermis from the dermis at the BMZ and subsequent progression to scarring.
  • It generally affects those older than 50 years and is of insidious onset with multiple remissions and exacerbations.

Clinical features:

Symptoms

  • Foreign body sensation
  • Redness
  • Watering
  • Light sensitivity
  • Pain
  • Blurry vision

Signs

  • Vesicles or bullae (blisters) on the conjunctiva
  • Conjunctival scarring
  • Dry eye
  • Corneal opacification
  • Symblepharon (fusion of the eyelid and conjunctiva)
  • Entropion (inward turning of the eyelid)
  • Trichiasis (misdirected eyelashes that rub against the cornea)

Treatment

There is no cure for OCP, but treatment can help to control the inflammation and scarring and prevent complications. Treatment options include:

  • Artificial tears
  • Lubricants
  • Topical steroids
  • Systemic steroids
  • Dapsone
  • Immunosuppressive therapy
  • Surgery (in severe cases)

Complications:

  • Inferior symblepharon:This is a condition in which the lower eyelid attaches to the conjunctiva (the clear tissue that covers the white part of the eye).
  • Severe dry eye:OCP can cause the tear glands to produce fewer tears, which can lead to dry eyes.
  • Entropion:This is a condition in which the eyelid turns inward, causing the eyelashes to rub against the cornea (the clear front part of the eye).
  • Keratinisation and consequent opacification of the cornea:OCP can also cause the cornea to become keratinised (hardened) and opaque.
  • Corneal perforation is a rare but serious complication of OCP. It occurs when the cornea develops a hole through it. This can be caused by severe dry eye, keratitis (inflammation of the cornea), or other factors.

questions.text: Which of the following management options for OCP yields poor results?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mucous membrane grafting is a challenging surgery with a high rate of complications.
  • The graft may not survive, or it may become scarred and contracted.
  • In addition, mucous membrane grafting does not always prevent the progression of OCP.
  • Overall, mucous membrane grafting is a high-risk surgery with a limited chance of success.
  • It is only recommended for patients with severe OCP who have failed other treatments.

Explanation of other options:

Artificial tears(Option A): Artificial tears are a safe and effective treatment for dry eye. They can help to relieve the symptoms of dryness, irritation, and discomfort.

Immunosuppressive therapy(Option B): Immunosuppressive therapy can be effective in reducing inflammation and slowing the progression of OCP. However, it is important to weigh the risks and benefits of immunosuppressive therapy before starting treatment.

Keratoprosthesis(Option D): A keratoprosthesis is an artificial cornea that can be implanted in patients with severe corneal opacification. It can be a life-changing surgery for patients with OCP, but it is also a complex surgery with several risks.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not implicated in Stevens-Johnson's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (erythema multiforme major) :

Causes: 

  • It is typically triggered by an immunological response to drugs such as: sulphonamides, NSAIDs, antibiotics, antimalarials, antiepileptics like barbiturates and phenytoin (Option A, B and C).
  • Systemic infections (caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, herpes simplex virus, and certain fungi) can also lead to it.
  • As per the references, there is no evidence of Tetracyclines being causative of Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
  • It is a Type II Hypersensitivity reaction.
  • It is a serious disease that can be fatal in some patients.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Skin Rash: It is characterised by a skin rash with erythematous lesions, which may progress to bullae formation.
  • Systemic Symptoms: Patients often experience fever and malaise.
  • Mucous Membrane Involvement: Ulcerative lesions of the mucous membranes, particularly in the mouth and eyes, are common.

Ocular Effects:

  • Late Ocular Sequelae: Ocular complications can occur, including severe dry eye, symblepharon (adhesions between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva), lid deformities (like cicatricial entropion), corneal vascularisation, and scarring.

Ocular Treatment:

  • Acute Stage:Treatment in the acute stage includes supportive therapy with topical lubricants, antibiotics to prevent secondary bacterial infections, and lysis of adhesions formed between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctivae. This is achieved by passing a glass rod coated with antibiotic or plain paraffin ointment in the fornices.
  • Late Cicatricial Stage:In the late cicatricial stage, medical treatment can be used to manage dry eye symptoms, and lid deformities can be surgically corrected.
  • Additional Measures:Additional measures may include punctal occlusion, transplantation of conjunctival or buccal mucous membrane, and transplantation of limbal stem cells with amniotic membrane to promote healing. These procedures aim to restore the integrity of the damaged ocular surface.

questions.text: Which of the following drug toxicity results in papillary conjunctival reaction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Certain chemicals and toxins, including drugs such as neomycin (Option A), gentamicin (Option C), idoxuridine (Option B), trifluorothymidine drops, preservatives in drops such as benzalkonium chloride and thiomersal, and prolonged topical use of eserine, pilocarpine or Phospholine Iodide, can produce follicular hypertrophy.
  • Atropine and Brimodine drug toxicity produce papillary response.

choices.text: Aggregates of epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in glands of Wolfring

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding concretion is/are true?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Concretions (lithiasis):

These occur as minute, hard, yellow spots in the palpebral conjunctiva.

Concretions are formed due to the accumulation of epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in depressions called Henle glands.

Clinical Features:

  • Foreign body sensation, as concretions can be so hard that when they project from the surface, the cornea is scratched (Option B).
  • They are common in elderly people who suffer from trachoma (Option C).

choices.text: Caused due to hyaline infiltration of submucosa
Triangular lesion with apex of triangle facing cornea

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Pinguencula is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Pinguecula:

It is due to hyaline infiltration and elastotic degeneration of the submucous tissue. It appears as a yellowish, raised lesion on the conjunctiva, typically nasal to the limbus. (Option A)

Clinical Features:

  • It is usually found in elderly people, especially those who are exposed to strong sunlight, dust and wind.
  • It occurs near the limbus in the palpebral aperture, the apex of the triangle being away from the cornea, and affects the nasal side first and then the temporal.
  • It is yellow and looks like fat, hence the name (pinguis, fat). Since the pinguecula remains relatively free from congestion, it is particularly conspicuous when the eye is inflamed; mistakes in diagnosis may then occur.

Treatment:

  • Pinguecula is usually asymptomatic and does not require surgical removal unless it's:
    Cosmetically concerning or chronically inflamed. Hence, Option C is not true regarding pinguicula.
  • In most cases, lubricating drops or anti-inflammatory drops are enough.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old farmer presents to OPD with complaints of redness, irritation and growth over the eye. Clinical imaging is as below.

Identify the lesion depicted in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Image depicted above is a Pterygium.

Pterygium:

Pterygium, meaning 'a wing,' is a triangular growth of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva that encroaches into the interpalpebral area of the eye.

Aetiopathogenesis:

  • It is an elastotic degenerative condition of the subconjunctival tissue, characterised by avascularized granulation tissue that invades the cornea, destroying superficial stromal layers and Bowman's membrane.
  • This condition is common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils, possibly due to exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light. Localised stem cell deficiency is also a risk factor.
  • It is loosely adherent to the sclera along its entire length.

Clinical Features:

  • Pterygium often follows a pinguecula.
  • Typically bilateral, commonly found on the nasal side of the eye.
  • Can impair vision due to induced astigmatism or progression into the pupillary area.
  • Induces astigmatism (with the rule) with corneal flattening along the axis of the pterygium.
  • Initially appears thick and vascular, but becomes thin, pale, and atrophic in later stages.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Pseudopterygium, which is a pterygium-like lesion, is induced by cicatricizing conjunctival inflammatory overgrowth produced by trauma, thermochemical burn or chronic conjunctivitis.
  • Distinguishing features include a nonprogressive nature, location at any quadrant of the corneal limbus and not necessarily being nasal, appearance with adhesions to the adjacent lid and scar tissue anchoring the lesion to the underlying surface, unlike a true pterygium, beneath which a probe can be passed at the edges.

Treatment:

  • Pterygium should be left alone unless it progresses toward the pupillary area, causes excessive astigmatism, restricts ocular motility, or is disfiguring.
  • Surgical removal involves:
    • Seizing the neck near the corneal margin with fixation forceps.
    • Raising and dissecting the pterygium from the cornea, starting from the apex.
    • Careful dissection to avoid going too deep.
    • Excising as much of the pterygium as possible.
    • Leaving a bare area of sclera at the edge of the cornea.
  • Recurrence can occur, and prevention methods include:
    • Postoperative therapy with mitomycin C drops (with associated complications).
    • Bare sclera technique for pterygium is most likely to be complicated by recurrence.
    • Using an autoconjunctival graft or an amniotic membrane graft, suturing it at the limbus to cover the excision site.
    • For recurring pterygium extending towards the pupillary area, freeing the apex, excising the lesion, and inserting a lamellar graft over the affected area. MMC can be tried during surgery and post-operatively to reduce recurrence

Explanation of other options:

Phlycten(Option A): nodular lesions situated near the imbus

Pinguencula(Option B): degenerative nodular lesions in the palpebral conjunctiva

Pannus(Option D): lymphocytic and vascular ingrowth into the cornea

questions.text: Identify the tumor type depicted in the imaging below.
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Dermoids and dermolipomas are not true neoplasms but are choristomas or a collection of heterotopic tissues (normal tissues in an abnormal location) which grow as tumours or tumour-like lesions.
  • Dermoids are lenticular yellow tumours, usually astride the corneal margin, most commonly at the outer side. They consist of epidermoid epithelium with sebaceous glands and hair, which may irritate.
  • Both limbal dermoids and dermolipomas are more common in children with a congenital developmental anomaly known as Goldenhar syndrome (oculoauriculovertebral dysplasia).
  • This syndrome affects structures derived from the first branchial arch, leading to preauricular tags, deformities of the external ear and vertebral anomalies.
  • Colobomas of the lids and iris, and Duane retraction syndrome are other associated ocular abnormalities.

Explanation of other options:

Hamartoma (Option B): Overgrowth of mature tissue in a normal site with disorganisation.

Angioma (Option C): Benign tumour made up of blood vessels.

Teratoma (Option D): Neoplasm containing all 3 germinal layers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding conjunctival lymphomas is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Conjunctival lymphoma occurs on the bulbar conjunctiva or in the fornix.
  • They are typically described as painless, slow-growing (Option B), salmon-coloured, i.e. light pinkish, mildly elevated, homogeneous lesions which can sometimes have small, round aggregations that look like fish eggs. Hence, Option A is incorrect regarding conjunctival lymphomas.
  • An excision biopsy must be done to determine the diagnosis. Systemic lymphoma may be associated; hence, a thorough systemic evaluation is mandatory.
  • Radiotherapy is effective in treating localised conjunctival lymphomas. Hence, Option C is incorrect about the conjunctival lymphomas.

choices.text: Ocular involvement can be first manifestation of systemic disease

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Kaposi sarcoma are correct except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Surgical treatment is not curative; it is treated palliatively with radiotherapy and other modalities.

Kaposi's Sarcoma:

  • Kaposi sarcoma is a highly vascular tumour associated with Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV/AIDS.
  • It affects the skin or any organ and is common in southern Mediterranean regions, Eastern Europe and Africa. If a conjunctival lesion is present, there is a high association with AIDS, and eye involvement can be the first manifestation.
  • The lesion may also affect the skin of the eyelids and face. The tumour is highly vascular, with a bluish red colour and presents as an elevated nodule somewhat resembling a subconjunctival haemorrhage.

Treatment:

The tumour often requires systemic management, such as:

  • HAART (for HIV)
  • Radiation therapy
  • Intralesional chemotherapy

High recurrence is possible if underlying immunosuppression is not corrected.

choices.text: Limbus is a common site for occurrence

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the condition depicted below is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The above picture is of a naevus or congenital mole.

Naevi or congenital moles are not uncommon. They are grey, gelatinous or pigmented nodules situated by preference at the limbus or near the plica semilunaris. (Option A)

They have the same structure as in the skin: groups, often alveolar, of 'naevus cells'in close connection with the epithelium. They are congenital and tend to grow at puberty, rarely becoming malignant. (Options B and C)

Given this, they should be excised completely before puberty, lest malignant changes follow the operative disturbance.

It is to be noted that pigmentation at the limbus occurs normally in people with dark complexions, and dark patches are not uncommon in them.

Key takeaways:

  • Pigmented tumours of the conjunctiva: some are simple (naevus), some are potentially precancerous (junctional naevus, precancerous melanosis, lentigo malignum), and some are frankly malignant (malignant melanoma).
  • Malignant Melanoma typically occurs at the limbus, is usually pigmented and occurs mostly in the elderly. It spreads over the surface of the globe but rarely penetrates it; recurrences and metastases occur as elsewhere in the body.
  • β-Irradiation, either primary or after tumour excision, is the treatment of choice for conjunctival melanomas.
  • Malignant lesions may become radioresistant, in which case the only effective treatment is wide excision with exenteration of the orbit and extensive reconstitution by skin grafting.
  • The neoplasm may be alveolar (derived from naevi) or round- or spindle-celled. The treatment is by excision of the globe or exenteration of the orbit. The image below is of Malignant melanoma.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old child presents to the OPD with complaints of poor vision at night. The child appears underweight for his age. Conjunctival examination is as depicted. The rest of the eye examination is normal.

Identify the lesion and cause.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above image is of a Bitot spot that occurs due to a Vitamin A deficiency. (Option D ruled out)
  • Night-blindness also occurs due to the same deficiency, and the given age group corresponds to the same diagnosis.
  • Bitot spot is characterised by small, triangular, white patches on the outer and inner sides of the cornea and covered by a material resembling dried foam, which is not wet by the tears.
  • These foamy spots are due to gas production by Corynebacterium xerosis present in the horny epithelium.
  • Pinguecula is a benign yellowish growth on the conjunctiva, usually due to UV exposure or ageing, and not related to vitamin deficiencies. (Options A and B ruled out)

Stagging of the eye manifestations due to Vitamin A deficiency:

Treatment:

Vit A orally once daily on Days 0, 1 and 14 according to age.

For children 6-12 months:

  • 100,000 IU of Vitamin A orally

For children ≥12 months:

  • 200,000 IU of Vitamin A orally

For infants <6 months:

  • 50,000 IU orally

questions.text: Which component/s of tear film is/are affected in Keratoconjunctivitis Sicca?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is a condition caused by a deficiency of the aqueous component of tears, i.e. the lacrimal secretion.

Components of the tear film:

  • The lipid layer is secreted by the meibomian glands.
  • The aqueous layer is secreted by the lacrimal glands.
  • The mucous layer is secreted principally by conjunctival goblet cells.

Keratoconjunctivitis Sicca:

  • It is a general, systemic and autoimmune disturbance usually occurring in women after the menopause and often associated with rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is characterised by a deficiency of the lacrimal secretion, leading to dryness of the eyes. This usually gives rise to chronic irritative symptoms and may be associated with epithelial erosions or filaments on the corneal surface.
  • Damage to the epithelium of the cornea and conjunctiva may be demonstrated clinically by staining with Rose Bengal.
  • Pathologically, the lacrimal gland is found to be fibrotic and infiltrated with lymphocytes; similar changes in the salivary glands may lead to a dryness of the mouth, while desiccation may occur in other mucous membranes.

Explanation of other options:

Mucinous (Option A): The mucin layer, secreted by conjunctival goblet cells, helps in spreading the tear film evenly across the cornea. Mucin deficiency is seen in ocular cicatricial pemphigoid and Stevens-Johnson syndrome, but not in KCS.

Lipid (Option C): The lipid layer, secreted by meibomian glands, reduces tear evaporation. Its deficiency causes Meibomian gland dysfunction/blepharitis, not classical KCS.

questions.text: Which systemic condition is associated with tear deficiency?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sjögren syndrome (SS) is an autoimmune disorder characterised by lymphocytic inflammation and destruction of lacrimal and salivary glands and other exocrine organs.
  • The classic clinical triad consists of dry eyes, dry mouth and parotid gland enlargement, but other features are common and can affect all organ systems.
  • Mucus from the goblet cells of the conjunctiva is necessary to keep the tear film stable. Lack of mucus causes premature breakup of the tear film even in the presence of abundant tear fluid.
  • Mucus deficiency occurs in Stevens-Johnson syndrome, ocular pemphigoid, avitaminosis, old trachoma or secondary to therapy with practolol. (Other options ruled out).

questions.text: Which of the following factors pre-dispose to dry eye?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Conditions that predispose to dry eye include:

  • Systemic collagen vascular disorders, especially rheumatoid arthritis, and Sjögren syndrome.
  • old age
  • diabetes mellitus
  • vitamin D deficiency
  • chronic use of topical ophthalmic medications
  • chronic conjunctivitis
  • chemical burns (Option A)
  • chronic cicatricizing inflammatory eye disorders such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome
  • ocular cicatricial pemphigoid
  • chronic use of contact lenses (Option B)
  • smoking
  • LASIK
  • Extensive and profound use of computers or viewing television, or other electronic devices, all predispose to dry eye (Option C).

The condition can be triggered or exacerbated by low relative humidity, dry office environment, air-conditioned cars or aeroplane cabins, and extreme weather conditions (hot/cold/windy).

Treatment of the Dry Eye:

  • Tear supplements: Several varieties of effective artificial tears are commercially available. The slow-release variety is a pellet of a cellulose compound without preservatives that is inserted below the tarsus of the lower lid, where it dissolves slowly, providing a continuous source of tears.
  • Preservation of the natural tears: Temporary occlusion of the puncta by inserting dissolvable collagen plugs, or permanent occlusion by inserting silicone plugs or by thermal cautery. Lateral tarsorrhaphy can also be performed to reduce evaporation of tears.
  • Excess mucus may be treated by acetyl cysteine 5% drops buffered to pH 8.4 with sodium bicarbonate.
  • Squamous metaplasia of the ocular surface epithelium may play a part in the production of symptoms. This abnormality can be reversed by the application of topical trans-retinoic acid ointment, with alleviation of discomfort.

questions.text: Which of the following test results further support diagnosis of dry eye?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tests for Tear Film Evaluation:

Tests for Tear Film Evaluation:

  • Tear film breakup time (TBUT):
    • Normal: >10 seconds.
    • Dry eye: <10 seconds. (Option A ruled out)
  • Tear film osmolarity:
    • Normal: 295 ± 9.5 mOsm/L.
    • Dry eye: >308 mOsm/L or inter-eye difference >8 mOsm/L. (Option B)
  • Schirmer test:
    • Normal: >10 mm wetting in 5 minutes.
    • Dry eye: <6 mm wetting. (Option C)

questions.text: Which deposits are seen in Argyrosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Argyrosis:

  • This is a deep brown staining of the conjunctiva from prolonged application of silver salts (silver nitrate, proteinate, etc.) for the treatment of chronic conjunctivitis and especially trachoma.
  • Since these drugs are seldom used, the condition is rarely seen nowadays.
  • The staining, which is most marked in the lower fornix, is due to the impregnation of reduced metallic silver into the elastic fibres in the membrane and vessel walls.

Explanation of other options:

Epinephrine (Option C): Causes Adenochrome deposits

Prostaglandins (Option D): Increased iris pigmentation

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient reports to the OPD with features of foreign body sensation and tearing. Clinical imaging is as depicted in the image below. Identify the lesion
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Conjunctivochalasis:

  • This is a condition that is seen in elderly people with laxity of the conjunctiva, leading to folds usually visibly heaped on the lid margin.
  • It can be asymptomatic or produce ocular discomfort due to 'dry' eye and a foreign body sensation with tearing.
  • Symptomatic relief can be provided by prescribing artificial tears four to six times a day, modifying the frequency as necessary.
  • Sometimes, surgical excision of redundant folds (conjunctivoplasty) is required.

Explanation of other options:

Pterygium(Option A): wing-shaped vascular growth from the conjunctiva to the cornea.

Pinguecula(Option B): degenerative nodular lesion.

Entropion(Option C): Inward turning of eyelashes and lid margin.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions do not predispose to Symblepharon formation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis does not predispose to symblepharon formation.

Symblepharon:

This is an adhesion between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctivae and occurs due to any condition which makes apposing surfaces raw and inflamed, allowing cicatrisation and fibrosis.

Causes:

  • Chemical and thermal burns (Option C)
  • cicatrising conjunctival diseases such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome (Option A)
  • pemphigoid (Option B)
  • Infection
  • Radiation
  • Post-surgical complications

questions.text: Goblet cells are seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Goblet cells are seen in the epithelium of the conjunctiva and help in tear production.

Conjunctiva:

  • The conjunctivais a transparent mucous membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelids and the anterior surface of the globe, terminating at the corneoscleral limbus.
  • It isrichly vascular, supplied by the anterior ciliary and palpebral arteries.
  • There is a dense lymphatic network, with drainage to the preauricular and submandibular nodes corresponding to that of the eyelids.
  • It has a key protective role, mediating both passive and active immunity.

Anatomically, it is divided into the following:

  • The palpebral conjunctiva starts at the mucocutaneous junction of the lid margins and is firmly attached to the posterior tarsal plates. The tarsal blood vessels are vertically orientated.
  • The fornix conjunctivae is loose and redundant.
  • The bulbar conjunctivacovers the anterior sclera and is continuous with the corneal epithelium at the limbus.
    • Radial ridges at the limbus form the palisades of Vogt, the likely reservoir of corneal stem cells.
    • The stroma is loosely attached to the underlying Tenon capsule, except at the limbus, where the two layers fuse.
    • The plica semilunaris(semilunar fold) is present nasally, medial to which lies a fleshy nodule (caruncle) consisting of modified cutaneous tissue.

Histology :

  • The epithelium is non-keratinising and around five cell layers deep.
  • Mucus-secreting goblet cells are located within the epithelium, being most dense inferonasally and in the fornices.
  • The stroma (substantia propria) consists of richly vascularized loose connective tissue.
  • The accessory lacrimal glands of Krause and Wolfring are located deep within the stroma. Secretions from the accessory lacrimal glands are essential components of the tear film.

Explanation of other options:

Epithelium of the Cornea (Option A): The corneal epithelium is non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and does not contain goblet cells.

Stroma of Conjunctiva (Option C): The stroma contains connective tissue, blood vessels, and lymphatics, but no goblet cells.

Bowman layer of the Cornea (Option D): The Bowman's layer is an acellular layer beneath the corneal epithelium and does not have goblet cells.

choices.text: Topical antibiotic is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Which is false regarding acute conjunctivitis
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Acute conjunctivitis is an inflammation of the conjunctiva and typically does not involve the cornea.
  • Therefore, corneal infiltration is not a feature of acute conjunctivitis

Explanation of other Options:

Pupil unaffected (Option A): In conjunctivitis, the inflammation is limited to the conjunctiva, and the pupil remains normal.

Vision is not affected (Option B): Vision is usually clear; however, mild blurring may occur due to discharge but not due to ocular pathology.

Topical antibiotic is the treatment of choice (Option C): Acute bacterial conjunctivitis responds well to topical broad-spectrum antibiotics.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics are treatment of choice

questions.text: Which is false regarding viral conjunctivitis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Topical antibiotics are effective in bacterial conjunctivitis, not viral.
  • In viral conjunctivitis, antibiotics are not the treatment of choice, although they may be used prophylactically to prevent secondary bacterial infection.

Explanation of other options:

Vision unaffected (Option A): Viral conjunctivitis usually causes redness, watery discharge, and irritation but does not affect vision.

Pupil unaffected (Option B): The pupil remains normal in viral conjunctivitis.

The Cornea is infiltrated (Option D): Viral conjunctivitis, especially adenoviral, can cause subepithelial corneal infiltrates as part of the immune response
